original_content:
Were so used to seeing a little sachet of desiccant drop out of a package when we open it, that we seldom consider these essential substances. But anyone who spends a while around 3D printing soon finds the need for drying their filament, and knowing a bit about the subject becomes of interest. Its refreshing then to see [Big Clive] do a side-by-side test of a range of commonly available desiccants. Of silica gel, bentonite, easy-cook rice, zeolite, or felight, which is the best? He subjects them to exactly the same conditions over a couple of months, and weighs them to measure their efficiency in absorbing water.
The results are hardly surprising, in that silica gel wins by a country mile. Perhaps the interesting part comes in exploding the rice myth; while the rice does have some desiccant properties, its in fact not the best of the bunch despite being the folk remedy for an immersed mobile phone.
Meanwhile, this isnt the first time weve looked at desiccants, in the past weve featured activated alumina.
title: 3Dプリンター用フィラメントを乾燥させるための各種除湿剤比較テスト
body: 開封時に乾燥剤を見るが、実態について考えない。3Dプリンタでフィラメントを乾燥する必要性が明らかに。シリカゲルが水分を最も吸収することが明らかに。米には吸湿性がありfolk remedyであるが、最適とは言えない。
titles: 3Dプリンター用フィラメントを乾燥させるための各種除湿剤比較テスト
シリカゲルが最も効果的：除湿剤比較テスト結果
除湿剤効果測定：シリカゲルvsベントナイトvs米など
ライスミステリー解明：米は除湿に効果的ではない？
除湿剤の選び方：アクティブアルミナやジオライトも視野に
